awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Food-Water-Energy Nexus: FEW-meter model to measure and improve urban agriculture, shifting it towards circular urban metabolism
awd_abstract_narration:
Many cities across the globe are facing difficult challenges managing their food, water and energy systems. The challenges stem from the fact that the issues of food, water and energy are often tightly connected with each other, not only locally but also globally. This is known as the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) nexus.  An effective solution to a local water problem may cause new local problems with food or energy, or cause new water problems at the global level. On a local scale, it is difficult to anticipate whether solutions to one issue in the nexus are sustainable across food, water and energy systems, both at the local and the global scale.  Innovative solutions that encompass the nexus are particularly important to enable cities to better manage their food, water and energy systems and understand the benefits and tradeoffs for different solutions.  

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 29-country initiative through the joint Belmont Forum- Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe.  The Sustainable Urbanization Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy Nexus is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together the fragmented research and expertise across the globe to find innovative solutions to the Food-Water-Energy Nexus challenge.  The call seeks to develop more resilient, applied urban solutions to benefit a much wider range of stakeholders. The rapid urbanization of the world's population underscores the importance of this focus. International partners were invited to develop solutions for this challenge.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

This project seeks to investigate whether scaling up existing forms of urban agriculture could exacerbate pressures on food-energy-water systems (FEWs) by increasing water and energy consumption and contributing to air and water pollution.  The project will employ an urban metabolism framework to create a comprehensive system to evaluate how different urban agriculture systems and practices perform with respect to food production and energy and water use and opportunities for increased efficiency. Data on the resource flows and impacts of urban agriculture will be gathered and analyzed over three years from 45 case studies in four cities in Europe (Dortmund, Gorzow, London, and Nantes) and one city in the U.S. (New York). The project uses a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods, including the measurement of resource use, material flow analysis, life cycle assessment, practitioner surveys, and design methodologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Food, Energy, Water Meter project (FEW Meter) analyzed the effects of urban agriculture on the nexus of food, energy, and water and human resources through an assessment of the material flows and social impacts of 74 allotment gardens, community gardens and community farms in five countries. In these gardens and farms, we measured all material infrastructure, tracked activities and outputs, and social benefits and impacts. We created a relational database (the ?FEW Meter?) enabling researchers and farmers and gardeners to share insights on the operational characteristics of their farms and gardens, the first international database of urban agriculture resource flows and social outcomes. To design the FEW Meter, the research team worked in consultation with farmers and gardeners in each study location to identify significant indicators of the material and human inputs of urban agriculture and the nexus of food, energy, water, and human resources. Over two growing seasons the farmers and gardeners, with assistance from the research team, measured food production, resources used (e.g., water, energy, fertilizers), garden and farm infrastructure composition, and the social impacts of urban farming and recorded these metrics in the FEW Meter database.

The research team analyzed the FEW-meter data using life-cycle assessment and material flow methods to estimate the food, energy, water nexus impacts of the projects, and identified scenarios for improved efficiency. One key finding was that significant variation in carbon footprint exists among UA types, and that garden and farm infrastructure (e.g., raised beds, greenhouses, pavement, etc.) is the primary source of greenhouse gas emissions associated with urban agriculture. Due to the importance of infrastructure in the carbon footprint, impacts grow dramatically if urban gardens and farms are relocated frequently; farms must remain for at least 10 years to avoid significantly raising the carbon footprint of urban crops compared to conventionally grown produce.

We demonstrated the importance of introducing the human element in this UA nexus study and coined the acronym food-water-energy-people (FEWP) to capture our methodological approach to data collection and analysis. To assess the social impacts of urban agriculture, the researchers surveyed gardeners and farmers, and analyzed the survey results to identify relationships among wellbeing, nutritional health, socialization and economic benefits of urban agriculture and farm and garden types. Our analysis identified significant differences in motivations and reported effects across different types of urban agriculture projects, different participant roles, the destination of the food grown, and the organizational structures of the farms and gardens. Our findings illustrate a method of urban agriculture evaluation that urban planners can use to tailor projects to address specific goals as they allocate municipal resources to support or scale up urban agriculture. In light of the COVID-19 pandemic we also examined the impact of the pandemic on the gardens and farms and the roles played by the gardens and farms in maintaining health and wellbeing among growers during the pandemic.

The research team analyzed urban agriculture nexus policies in the study cities, interviewing experts and identifying policy factors that are key for the promotion of resource efficiency and the scaling up of urban agriculture. For each country, researchers identified stakeholders from government and non-profit organizations with knowledge of food policies related to urban agriculture. Stakeholders and researchers aggregated and analyzed food policies, sustainability agendas, urban development plans, and strategies that influence resource efficiency in urban agriculture. We identified 16 types of policies most promising to promote resource-efficient urban agriculture. 

Finally, we worked with research partners to conduct two experiments that tested the potential of urban agriculture to affect the nexus through soil remediation and use of organic waste with an innovative micro anaerobic digester.
